Text:
Top 10 Most Popular Open-Source Databases  This list is based on factors like adoption, industry impact, and the general awareness of the database among the developer community.  1 - MySQL 2 - PostgreSQL 3 - MariaDB 4 - Apache Cassandra 5 - Neo4j 6 - SQLite 7 - CockroachDB 8 - Redis 9 - MongoDB 10 - Couchbase  Over to you: Which other database would you add to this list?-- Subscribe to our weekly newsletter to get a Free System Design PDF (158 pages): https://bit.ly/3KCnWXqhashtag#systemdesign hashtag#coding hashtag#interviewtips .

Text: Chère réseau LinkedIn,J'ai l'honneur de partager avec vous un aperçu de notre projet de fin d'année, réalisé en collaboration avec mon binôme, Oussama Chaabene. Sous la supervision de Mr Mohamed Ali Hadj Taieb, nous avons développé une solution de traitement et d'analyse de données en temps réel pour des transactions simulées d'un site e-commerce.Notre projet vise à démontrer comment une architecture de traitement de données en flux peut fournir des insights précieux en temps réel sur les transactions et le comportement des utilisateurs d'une plateforme e-commerce.Je tiens à remercier mon binôme, Oussama Chaabene, et notre encadrant, Mr Mohamed Ali Hadj Taieb, pour leur soutien et leur collaboration tout au long de ce projet.
Comments: [{'comment': 'Congratulations ', 'replies': None, 'replies_count': 0}, {'comment': 'Nice to work with you mate ❤️ ❤️', 'replies': None, 'replies_count': 0}, {'comment': 'Great job, keep going ', 'replies': None, 'replies_count': 0}, {'comment': 'Félicitations\xa0!', 'replies': None, 'replies_count': 0}]

Text:
Discover the Right Database for Your Needs!For any data-driven professional, understanding the different types of databases is crucial. Without this knowledge, you run the risk of making costly mistakes. Here is a quick guide to help you navigate the unique characteristics of each category:==============================Updated infographic on popular demand.==============================🔶 Relational Databases⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯❇️ Description: Store data in tables with predefined schemas and relationships between them.❇️ Examples: SQL Server, PostgreSQL, Oracle🔶 NoSQL Databases⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯❇️ Document Stores: Store data as documents, often in JSON or BSON format. Examples: MongoDB, CouchDB❇️ Key-Value Stores: Store data as key-value pairs for fast retrieval. Examples: Redis, DynamoDB, Riak❇️ Columnar Databases: Store data in columns instead of rows, optimised for analytical queries. Examples: Apache Cassandra, HBase❇️ Graph Databases: Store data as graphs, managing entities and their relationships. Examples: Neo4j, Amazon Neptune❇️ Time Series Databases: Optimised for handling time-stamped or time-series data. Examples: InfluxDB, TimescaleDB❇️ Object-oriented Databases: Store data as objects used in object-oriented programming. Examples: ObjectDB, db4o🔶 Specialised Databases⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯❇️ In-Memory Databases: Store data primarily in memory for fast data retrieval. Examples: Redis, SAP HANA, Memcached❇️ Vector Databases: Designed to store efficiently, index, and search high-dimensional vectors. Examples: FAISS, Annoy, Milvus, PineconeEach type has strengths and use cases, so choosing the right one for your needs is essential. Which database type do you find most exciting or use frequently in your projects?hashtag#DataScience hashtag#Database hashtag#BigData hashtag#NoSQL hashtag#RelationalDatabases hashtag#MachineLearning

Text:
Basic understanding of of DAG in Spark....DAG in Spark---It is a fundamental concept in the execution model of Spark's processing engine.D-Directed A-Acyclic G-GraphA DAG is created to represent the sequence of transformations(Narrow & Wide) that need to be executed. Spark's Catalyst optimizer then optimizes this DAG to minimize the amount of data movement and computation needed.Default Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) workflow in Streaming Engine--1st  Image - Stage(0->1) Dag Processing.  -- Single Layer Workflow2nd Image - Stage(0->n) Dag Processing.  -- Multi Layer Workflow







    Voir la traduction

Today, let's explore different types of algorithms that help machines uncover patterns and make predictions, even without explicit instructions.𝟭. 𝗦𝘂𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗶𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴: Imagine teaching a child to differentiate between fruits and vegetables by showing them examples. Supervised learning works similarly, where the computer is taught with data that is already labeled. It's like having a guide while exploring a new city!- Classification: It's about putting things into categories. For example, deciding if an email is spam or not is a classification problem. - Regression: This is about predicting numbers, like forecasting sales for the next month.𝟮. 𝗨𝗻𝘀𝘂𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗶𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴: Now, imagine trying to organize a box of toys without knowing what they are. Unsupervised learning is when the machine tries to make sense of data without any labels, discovering hidden patterns on its own.- Clustering: It's like finding groups of friends in a crowd based on their interests. - Association: This helps in identifying items that often go together, like bread and butter.𝟯. 𝗦𝗲𝗺𝗶-𝗦𝘂𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗶𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴: This is a mix of the above two. Think of it as learning to cook with some recipes and sometimes experimenting on your own. It uses both labeled and unlabeled data for training.𝟰. 𝗥𝗲𝗶𝗻𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗰𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴: Imagine teaching a dog new tricks by rewarding it with treats. Reinforcement learning works by rewarding the machine for correct decisions, helping it learn through trial and error.Whether it's automating tasks, making predictions, or improving decision-making, machine learning is reshaping how we interact with technology every day!➡ Stay tuned and make sure to follow us at Data and AI Central 🚀 for more FREE resources!hashtag#datascience hashtag#python hashtag#data hashtag#machinelearning hashtag#ai hashtag#artificialintelligence hashtag#programming hashtag#analytics hashtag#coding hashtag#tech hashtag#technology

Text:
A fantastic visual demonstration of CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks) and how they work! 🧠This video shows that making an image smaller doesn't always mean you lose important details. It's impressive that even though the image is much smaller, we can clearly see it shows a dog.This means if only about 25% of the starting image has enough clues to figure out what it is, we can just focus on that part. This way, we don't have to work with the whole image in CNNs, which makes things simpler and faster.👉 Follow Gina Acosta Gutiérrez 👩🏻‍💻 for more!➡ Get the latest AI insights, tools, tutorials and guides on using popular AI tools for FREE here: https://lnkd.in/d9rV2Mpmhashtag#python hashtag#data hashtag#machinelearning hashtag#ai hashtag#artificialintelligence hashtag#programming hashtag#coding hashtag#tech

Text:
As tech professionals, understanding database options is crucial. Today, we'll explore the main types and their best uses:Join me for a  FREE workshop and discover how to dramatically boost your MongoDB performance by 100x for Analytics and AI.✅ RSVP here - https://brij.guru/aiHere's what you'll learn:• Proven techniques to optimize your MongoDB queries • Configuration tweaks for a significant performance jump • Practical strategies to handle large datasets efficiently • How to  to achieve 100x faster aggregations and analytics on your JSON data • See real-world benchmarks showcasing the performance difference on sample queries. • Learn about real-time CDC integration from MongoDB® using a native CDC connector.Relational Databases (RDBMS):  The workhorses! Think MySQL, Oracle, SQL Server. These organize data in tables with clear relationships, making them perfect for complex queries and data integrity. They're the go-to for most business applications.NoSQL Databases:  Flexibility is key here! MongoDB and Cassandra are popular examples. NoSQL handles unstructured data with ease and boasts impressive performance for massive datasets. Ideal for big data, content management, and real-time applications.Graph Databases:  Let's get connected! Neo4j shines when it comes to networked data and social relationships. Graph databases excel at fraud detection, recommendations, and knowledge graphs.Time Series Databases:  All about the time! InfluxDB is built for timestamped, sequenced data. It's a great fit for IoT, DevOps, and sensor data analysis.Object Databases: Think objects, not tables! db4o is an example here. Object databases excel at working with media files, search engines, and engineering design systems.Choosing the Right Database:  It's all about your needs! Data structure, relationships, scalability, and performance all play a role. A solid grasp of the options empowers you to architect optimal systems and leverage the best tools.Have I overlooked anything? Please share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.







    Voir la traduction

Text:
Elevate Your Coding Game with Top Python Libraries! 🚀Python enthusiasts, it's time to dive into the ocean of libraries that make our lives easier. Whether you're manipulating data with hashtag#Pandas, crafting cutting-edge hashtag#MachineLearning models with hashtag#ScikitLearn, or visualizing data with hashtag#Matplotlib, Python’s versatility is unrivaled.🔍 Data Manipulation:Effortlessly handle data with hashtag#NumPy for numerical operations, hashtag#Polars for lightning-fast data frames, or hashtag#Vaex for out-of-core dataframes.📊 Data Visualization:Bring your data to life with hashtag#Plotly, create interactive plots with hashtag#Bokeh, or map your insights with hashtag#Folium.📈 Statistical Analysis:Model your data with hashtag#SciPy, make probabilistic predictions with hashtag#PyMC3, or conduct survival analysis with hashtag#Lifelines.🤖 Machine Learning:Build neural networks with hashtag#TensorFlow, get experimental with hashtag#JAX, or stay classic with hashtag#Keras.🗣️ Natural Language Processing:Parse text with hashtag#NLTK, delve into deep learning with hashtag#BERT, or analyze language with hashtag#spaCy.💾 Database Operations:Streamline processes with hashtag#Dask, manage large-scale data with hashtag#Hadoop, or tap into real-time data streams with hashtag#Kafka.🕒 Time Series Analysis:Forecast the future with hashtag#Prophet, leverage hashtag#AutoTS for automated models, or extract features with hashtag#tsfresh.🌐 Web Scraping:Navigate web content with hashtag#BeautifulSoup, automate browser actions with hashtag#Selenium, or speed through scraping with hashtag#Scrapy.Python is the toolbox for modern developers. It’s time to leverage these powerful libraries to innovate and optimize your projects. What’s your go-to Python library?hashtag#Python hashtag#DataScience hashtag#WebDevelopment hashtag#AI hashtag#Analytics hashtag#BigData hashtag#Tech hashtag#Coding hashtag#Programming hashtag#Developer







    Voir la traduction

Top 5 Kafka use casesKafka was originally built for massive log processing. It retains messages until expiration and lets consumers pull messages at their own pace.Let’s review the popular Kafka use cases.- Log processing and analysis- Data streaming in recommendations- System monitoring and alerting- CDC (Change data capture)- System migrationOver to you: Do you have any other Kafka use cases to share?--Subscribe to our weekly newsletter to get a Free System Design PDF (158 pages): https://bit.ly/3KCnWXqhashtag#systemdesign hashtag#coding hashtag#interviewtips.







    Voir la traduction
Comments: [{'comment': 'In event driven architecture, for the asynchronous communication between service to service.', 'replies': ['Sumeet Chandra Yes you can use RabbitMQ and Amazon SNS as well. But every tool has its own limitation. For example, SNS does not support multiple consumers for the same message whereas RabbitMQ has the additional feature of supporting the priority queue. So, it depends on your requirements what you will choose for your architecture.'], 'replies_count': 1}, {'comment': ' Alex Xu What is the difference between a socket and a kafka? Same thing we can achieve with a pusher.', 'replies': ['Socket does not give any message storage. If consumer is down and producer sends message to a socket, message will be lost, whereas in Kafka, producer and consumer are decoupled. Even if consumer is down, producer can keep sending data without any data loss.Same goes for scalability. Because websockets are tightly coupled, consumers have to scale according to the producer. In Kafka, producer can lag behind and Kafka will act as a buffer.'], 'replies_count': 1}, {'comment': 'Wonder how it can be used for system monitoring and alerting? What popular tools can be integrated with Kafka?', 'replies': ["Mutha Nagavamsi You can assess the drop percentage of your important metrics by employing a rate of change calculation. If this decline exceeds the threshold you've established, you can trigger an alert. This can be facilitated through various tools such as Flink, Kafka, and Slack"], 'replies_count': 1}, {'comment': "We've conducted log analysis with Kafka as our initial landing point. However, we've noticed increased latency when retrieving logs from Kafka, which poses a challenge. Another concern is the complexity of implementing log modification and indexing pipelines without introducing Logstash between Kafka and Elasticsearch. This additional layer would complicate the stack and potentially make troubleshooting more challenging. Personally, I've found a simpler solution: forwarding logs using a dedicated log forwarder and then receiving them with Logstash before indexing them into Elasticsearch. This streamlined approach greatly simplifies our workflow and enhances efficiency.", 'replies': ["Tamilarasan Janakiramani had a similar situation.   Take a look at vector.dev.   You can log forward and ETL all with with the same stack and it's super fast "], 'replies_count': 1}, {'comment': 'How do you make these diagrams ? ✅💯', 'replies': ['canva or https://drawio-app.com/blog/connector-styles-and-animations-in-draw-io/'], 'replies_count': 1}, {'comment': 'Another key Kafka use case worth highlighting is IoT Data Integration. Text:
𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝘀 𝗞𝗮𝗳𝗸𝗮?Apache Kafka is a distributed, fault-tolerant, and highly scalable pub-sub messaging system. It enables applications to both publish and subscribe to real-time data feeds, boasting high throughput for both producers and consumers of record streams, and facilitating the real-time processing of these data streams.𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝘀 𝗞𝗮𝗳𝗸𝗮 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴?Kafka Streams is a powerful client library for stream processing, deeply integrated with Apache Kafka. It allows for the transformation and analysis of data stored in Kafka topics.𝗞𝗮𝗳𝗸𝗮 𝘃𝘀. 𝗭𝗲𝗿𝗼-𝗖𝗼𝗽𝘆 𝗞𝗮𝗳𝗸𝗮: 𝗗𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗰𝘁 𝗙𝗲𝗮𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝘀Traditional Kafka is renowned for its rapid data processing capabilities. However, 'zero-copy' Kafka enhances this further by utilizing an optimized data transfer mechanism. It circumvents the traditional application layer, transferring data directly from the file system cache to the network socket buffer. This minimizes CPU overhead and reduces data copying (hence 'zero-copy'), resulting in significantly improved throughput and reduced latency. Essentially, Zero-Copy Kafka provides an accelerated version of Kafka, tailored for even more efficient data handling.𝗧𝗼𝗽 𝟱 𝗞𝗮𝗳𝗸𝗮 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗖𝗮𝘀𝗲𝘀:1. 𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴: Kafka acts as a real-time conduit for high-volume data streams, analogous to channeling a dynamic river of information. It empowers the creation of applications that are capable of immediate data transformation and reaction as the information flows between various systems.2. 𝗟𝗼𝗴 𝗔𝗴𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: Kafka addresses the challenge of managing colossal volumes of log data generated every second. It provides a unified, high-throughput, and low-latency platform for handling real-time data feeds, thereby becoming an optimal solution for efficient log aggregation in distributed system architectures.3. 𝗠𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗤𝘂𝗲𝘂𝗲: In modern architectures, particularly those employing microservices, Kafka serves as an advanced message queuing system. It offers significant advantages over traditional message queues, with its inherent scalability, built-in fault tolerance, replication capabilities, and high durability.4. 𝗪𝗲𝗯 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴: Kafka is adept at meticulously tracking web activities such as page views, searches, and uploads, in a real-time and large-scale manner. It acts as a continuous monitor of user interactions on websites, providing invaluable insights for user experience enhancements.5. 𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗥𝗲𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: Kafka plays a pivotal role in the reliable and consistent transfer of data between different systems. It acts as a robust and fault-tolerant medium, ensuring seamless data replication and synchronization across distributed systems.➡ Stay tuned and make sure to follow us at Data and AI Central 🚀 for more FREE resources!hashtag#data hashtag#datascience hashtag#technology hashtag#programming hashtag#coding hashtag#tech hashtag#learning
